TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.TRANSL: There was a couple called Sapulungan and Muakai.

S.FORM: ti Muakai a nguanguaq aravats matu qadaw.
ti Moakai a ngoangoaq aravac mato qadaw.
S.TRANSL: Muakai was as beautiful as the sun.
But when they slept together,
Muakai had no hole in her private parts.
So Sapulungan was angry.

S.FORM: nu keman tua kinsa, nu temkel tua vava, inika pukaui a kilinguł, limutseng sakamaya.
no keman toa kinsa, no temkel toa vava, inika pokaoi a kilingolj, limoceng sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: When they ate or drank, he refused to sit (in a circle) with the others; he just sulked.

S.FORM: qau muri vaik a qemałup ti Sapulungan.
qao mori vaik a qemaljop ti Sapolongan.
S.TRANSL: Then Sapulungan was going off hunting,
and had left his pipe in the house.
“Come here, mother, hand me my pipe.”
Muakai took the pipe and gave it to him.
“No, put it back.
Tell my mother to give it to me.”

S.FORM: alapen nua kina sa pavayan tjai Sapulungan.
alapen noa kina sa pavayan tjai Sapolongan.
S.TRANSL: So his mother took it and gave it to Sapulungan.

S.FORM: "anema nu vavayanan a namaitazua a kutji sakamaya, neka nu buang?"
"anema no vavayanan a namaitazoa a kotji sakamaya, neka no boang?"
S.TRANSL: “What sort of woman is that with no hole in her private parts?”
“No wonder you are angry.”
“Give a drinking party for all the village.
Give the best beer (to her);

S.FORM: nu mapulaw anga, pai patsunu anga."
no mapolaw anga, pai pacono anga."
S.TRANSL: and when she is drunk, have a look.”
His mother got the villagers to make beer.

S.FORM: ka makesanga a vava, patsunin a tjałasanguaqan a vava, sa "tekeli kati Muakai," aya, sa tekelen na maḍusa.
ka makesanga a vava, paconin a tjaljasangoaqan a vava, sa "tekeli kati Moakai," aya, sa tekelen na madrosa.
S.TRANSL: When the beer was ready, she found the best beer, and said: “Muakai, let’s drink together,” and the two of them drank it (or “Let’s drink with Muakai;” and they drank with her).

S.FORM: ka mapulaw anga ti Muakai, seqereng a sema surur.
ka mapolaw anga ti Moakai, seqereng a sema soror.
S.TRANSL: When Muakai was drunk, she lay down on the bed platform.

S.FORM: izua qaliqali a maisuisu i tsasaw.
izoa qaliqali a maisoiso i casaw.
S.TRANSL: There was someone pounding grain outside.
“I’ll close the window, friend,

S.FORM: mana nu malavu ti su ḍava."
mana no malavo ti so drava."
S.TRANSL: in case the chaff goes on your friend.”
She undid Muakai’s clothes.
“What my son says is quite right.

S.FORM: manu namaitutsu, a neka nu buang."
mano namaitoco, a neka no boang."
S.TRANSL: So it’s like that; there’s no hole.”

S.FORM: azua buang matu tsalinga nua łigim.
azoa boang mato calinga noa ljigim.
S.TRANSL: The hole was like the eye of a needle.

S.FORM: malap ta siqunu a kina, sa tsukisen a seman buang.
malap ta siqono a kina, sa cokisen a seman boang.
S.TRANSL: His mother took a knife and cut a hole.

S.FORM: ka mapapaulingaw, "alapu tua załum, sa su pavanaw."
ka mapapaolingaw, "alapo toa zaljom, sa so pavanaw."
S.TRANSL: When Muakai was sober, his mother said: “Get some water and bathe yourself.”

S.FORM: malap tua załum ti Muakai, sa pavanaw.
malap toa zaljom ti Moakai, sa pavanaw.
S.TRANSL: Muakai got some water, and bathed herself.

S.FORM: ka mavanaw anga, samałi anga sakamaya.
ka mavanaw anga, samalji anga sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: When she had bathed, she was very surprised.
“Why is it like this?
There’s a hole now in my private parts.”
His mother looked.
“What’s up with you, Muakai?
Why are you behaving like that?”
“Well, look at my private parts.”

S.FORM: "kana vavayan namaitutsu a mapułat; inika amin sun a namaitazua.
"kana vavayan namaitoco a mapoljat; inika amin son a namaitazoa.
S.TRANSL: “Every woman is like that. It’s not only you.

S.FORM: mana sika limutsemutseng ni Sapulungan tjanusun."
mana sika limocemoceng ni Sapolongan tjanoson."
S.TRANSL: That’s why Sapulungan was angry with you.”
“Oh, mother, so that was it.”

S.FORM: ka mangtjengtjez anga ti Sapulungan, vaik a kina a kitsevungan a mapedjelidjeli.
ka mangtjengtjez anga ti Sapolongan, vaik a kina a kicevongan a mapedjelidjeli.
S.TRANSL: When Sapulungan came back, his mother went to meet him laughing.

S.FORM: mintuluq ti Sapulungan, temavikił tjai Muakai, sana ivulungan, sana puałak.
mintoloq ti Sapolongan, temavikilj tjai Moakai, sana ivolongan, sana poaljak.
S.TRANSL: Sapulungan ran and embraced Muakai; they had intercourse; and had a child.
And they all lived happily ever after.
amin
